paragraphs.text: So how do I replace wireframes? To be honest I’m not entirely sure. I’m going to try providing storyboards (similar to a movie) showing the interplay between screens and clickable prototypes. Both deliverables are much more collaborative, easier to test & discuss, and add context that might be missing from the spec. I have no idea if those things will be accepted by my team but there’s little lost by trying.
paragraphs.name: 6e31

paragraphs.text: Totally agree. My teams have moved away from wire framing in the traditional sense and instead stick to white boarding to keep fidelity low to start with and then incorporate flow details and paths in our hi fidelity Sketch docs so we have single design files. Also makes it easier to keep updated over time rather than 2 files that can get out of sync.
paragraphs.name: 3c65

6a4a05eced8c.title: Ever so often I read a ‘no more wireframes’ post and my initial thought is ‘they don’t get what…

paragraphs.text: Ever so often I read a ‘no more wireframes’ post and my initial thought is ‘they don’t get what wireframes are’. Wireframes, once upon a time, used to be a detailed specification document that outlines the exact behaviour of all aspects of an app/site. Now and again I still find people who make them and have to say — stop! Wireframes, in essence, are…

paragraphs.text: I never did wireframes. I do „roadbooks“. They show the actual design, the actual interactions (verbally and with a storybook like approach). Nearly nothing is undetermined. And yet. Lots of developers I’m working with aren’t understanding the benefit of „drawing by numbers“. In fact they don’t even read the treatments. Sometimes I’m doing mockups…
paragraphs.name: 6d0a

paragraphs.text: I can only say, that if your wireframes are taking too long, “aren’t agile” and aren’t in agreement with any technical specifications, you have some fundamental process and communication issues.

cffae13fbd6.title: It totally agree with regards to user testing.

paragraphs.text: It totally agree with regards to user testing. Simple, static wireframes do not provide much inside, as the user is basically browsing through a set of images. It´s better to use some prototyping tool to create a low-fi prototype and test with it. Those interactive prototypes feel usually more natural and allow you to understand the user behavior in more detail.
paragraphs.name: 288d

paragraphs.text: Exactly that´s the key. Wireframes are great! But you shoudn´t make one single screen if you haven´t sketch all the (or at least the most of it) user flow first. Once you´ve tested your sketchs with your team and /or stakeholders then you can start building wireframes, that way you will build essentialy what you know it´s on the right path. Maybe you…
paragraphs.name: 5a57

virtuals.subtitle: Maybe the are some companies (people) that has the culture of wireframing all, the problem isn’t wireframes, the problem its the…

paragraphs.text: This is very true! I see this challenge arise all the time. I’ve moved from wire framing to prototyping, because when prototyping it’s much easier to show the interaction model to development, figure out more of the visuals and get in front of users to test. Maybe prototyping takes more time upfront, but overall it seems to add a lot more clarity and…

I completely agree Bryce. I don’t think people have any understanding of how much time even simple wireframes take to make, factoring in breaks/devices/scaling and all the rest. I always feel that they provide little context and even a small change that needs to be actioned across them all can mean ages spent making adjustments across multiple…
paragraphs.name: d774

bf34a02a0502.title: Hi Bryce, totally agree that the ROI in case of wireframes is often unclear.

paragraphs.text: Hi Bryce, totally agree that the ROI in case of wireframes is often unclear. In our team we do really lo-fi digital wireframing(using something like Paper by 53) and build a flows using the same lo-fi screens.

paragraphs.text: I can understand your pain. While I was reading this I couldn’t help but think how valuable wireframing is for me and my team. It might be that our definition of a wireframe is different that yours. It may seem unnecessary, but it could help readers understand exactly what you are talking about.

virtuals.subtitle: For us, wireframing is sketching out the layout, workflows, and interactions of a given solution tied to the use cases or requirements…

content.subtitle: For us, wireframing is sketching out the layout, workflows, and interactions of a given solution tied to the use cases or requirements…

d958ef06cf17.title: All of what you say…so true.

paragraphs.text: All of what you say…so true. What’s worse is that wireframes are often used as a design tool by people who lack the vocabulary, skill, and patience do real architecture, design, and specification, but still want to be the “mouthpiece” for the product and get their ideas out first. The blessing and the curse of a wireframe are that it’s so easy to…
paragraphs.name: 3c41

52e7e8bb8cf1.title: To our team, wireframes are just a means to an end, which in our case is full-fidelity prototype.

paragraphs.text: To our team, wireframes are just a means to an end, which in our case is full-fidelity prototype. We don’t skip the step of wireframing, but depending on the complexity of the project, level of interaction, we spend enough time in the wireframes to make sure we have enough detail before we move to full-fidelity quickly. As we move downstream in the…
paragraphs.name: a16f

paragraphs.text: I somehow had a similar experience like you at the agency I’m working at. We believe the value of a wireframe is the logic behind it, the strategy. For the last two projects I worked closely with a ux designer mainly on a whiteboard. Each participant had their own marker and we just drew all day and took pictures of it, put it on trello in our own…
